resources.string: A játékban történt nagyobb változások miatt az univerzumod újraindult. Megteszek mindent, hogy a jövőbeli verziókban ne fordúljon elő hasonló.
Helytelen felhasználónév, csak betűk és számok elfogadottak
A ranglista megtekintéséhez, be kell jelentkezned
Megadhatsz egy jelszót, hogy más eszközről is hozzáférj a fiókodhoz
A felhasználónév regisztrálásra kerül, ha nincs használatban
Világító anyagokat Nyersanyagok felhasználásával lehet venni.
Építsd fel a világod az Atomoktól egy egész Galaxis-ig
Minnél több anyagod van, annál nagyobb a Nyersanyag termelésed
Az építkezés fülnél új anyagokat fedezhetsz fel
A világod akkor is növekszik, ha nem nem vagy bejelentkezve!
Ne feledd megnézni a helyezésed a ranglistán
Ha rákattintasz bármely számra, megváltozik a kijelzési módja.
Fordítás TR: Halil Kopuz, Deniz Kağan Dursun
Fordítás DE: Robert B. Lavars, Thomas Kupka
A bevételed növekedni fog, de az univerzumod megsemmisül. A pontjaid megmaradnak.
Túl lassú? Nézze meg a fekete lyukszorzót
Több elemre van szükséged, hogy ezt kifejleszd
A követelmények nem teljesültek, kérlek nézd meg újra
Váratlan fejlesztés, az univerzum mégt alakul
Tér idő kontunuum veszélyes, az időutazás jelenleg nem elérhető. Próbáld meg késöbb.
Ha az univerzumod elég nagy, akkor össze omolhat, és felfalhatja egy Fekete Lyuk. Az új bevételed az univerzumod nagyságától fog függni
Az egész univerzumod el fog tünni
Az univerzumod minden része meg fog semmisülni, a játékod előröl indul, de minden bevételed meg lesz többszörözve a Fekete Lyukad által
Menj vissza, és építsd az univerzumod nagyobbra, és szélesebbre
Vagy többet szerezhetsz az univerzumoddal, egy Fekete Lyuk segítségével
Csúsztassa ▶ a rendelkezésre álló bónuszok megtekintéséhez
Adj meg egy felhasználónevet a ranglistához
Megduplázhatod a bevételed egy reklám megnézésével
Köszönöm, hogy frissítetted a játékot. Pár nagyobb változás miatt sajnos újra kell kezd az univerzumod
Ezek a változások szükségesek a jövőbeli Idle World fejlesztéséhez. De választhatsz, hogy megtartod a Fekete Lyukad szorzóját, vagy teljesen újra kezded.
Köszönöm az elkötelezettséged a játék fejlődése mellett!
Helyi mentések, amelyeket az eszközön tárol. Gyors, nincs szükség internetkapcsolatra.
Az online felhő tárolja a mentést. Lehetővé teszi több eszköz lejátszását.
Az összes felhőben tárolt játék megjelenítése
Nem sikerült bejelentkezni. Ellenőrizze a hálózati kapcsolatot, és próbálja újra a beállításokat.
Hiba történt bejelentkezéskor. Próbálja meg később a beállításokat.
Ez a beállítás bármikor megváltoztatható a beállításokban.
Nincs internetkapcsolat. Az offline állapot visszaállítása.
Mint a macska és a kutya
The string theory assumes that the basic building blocks of matter are strings of magnitude 10–31 meters. The original string theory, called the theory of boson strings, was established in 1970
Quantum foam is a concept in quantum mechanics devised by John Wheeler in 1955. The foam is conceptualized as the foundation of the fabric of the Universe
Neutrino belongs to elementar particles. It\'s a fermion and i\'ts electrically nautral
The Higgs boson is an elementary particle that was discovered during experiments conducted in the Large Hadron Collider in CERN
A photon is an elementary particle that does not have an electrical charge. It\'s also a quanta of electromagnetic field, such as visible light.
A quark is a type of elementary particle and a fundamental constituent of matter. Quarks combine to form composite particles like protons and neutrons
The electron is a subatomic particle, with a negative elementary electric charge
The neutron is a subatomic particle, with no net electric charge and a mass slightly larger than that of a proton. Protons and neutrons constitute the nuclei of atoms
A proton is a subatomic particle, with a positive electric charge and mass slightly less than that of a neutron. Protons and neutrons are collectively referred to as "nucleons".
The positron is the antiparticle or the antimatter counterpart of the electron. The positron has an electric charge of +1 e and has the same mass as an electron.
The atomic nucleus is the small, dense region consisting of protons and neutrons at the center of an atom. Almost all of the mass of an atom is located in the nucleus
An atom is the smallest constituent unit of ordinary matter. Every solid, liquid, gas, and plasma is composed of neutral or ionized atoms
Plasma is a state of matter resembling an ionised gas. It is one of the four fundamental states of matter, and was first described by chemist Irving Langmuir in the 1920s.
Sound is a vibration that propagates as an audible wave of pressure, through a gas, liquid or solid. Humans can hear sound waves with frequencies between about 20Hz and 20kHz
An ion beam is a type of charged particle beam consisting of ions. Some ion beams derive from the mercury vapor thrusters developed by NASA in the 1960s.
Isotopes are variants of a particular chemical element which differ in neutron number. All isotopes of a given element have the same number of protons in each atom.
Hydrogen is a chemical element with symbol H and atomic number 1. It is the lightest element on the periodic table, highly flammable.
Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6. It is nonmetallic. Carbon is one of the few elements known since antiquity.
Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8. It is a highly reactive nonmetal. By mass, oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe.
Iron is a chemical element with symbol Fe. It is by mass the most common metal on Earth, forming much of Earth\'s outer and inner core.
Xenon is a chemical element with symbol Xe. It is a colorless, dense, odorless noble gas found in the Earth\'s atmosphere in trace amounts.

Water is a transparent and colorless chemical substance that is the main constituent of Earth\'s lakes, oceans, and the fluids of most living organisms. Its chemical formula is H2O, meaning that its molecule contains one oxygen and two hydrogen atoms.
Salt is a mineral composed of sodium chloride (NaCl). Salt is essential for life in general, and saltiness is one of the basic human tastes.
Sand is a naturally occurring granular material composed of finely divided rock and mineral particles.The most common constituent of sand is silica (SiO2).
Hemoglobin is the iron-containing metalloprotein in the red blood cells. Hemoglobin in the blood carries oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body.
A carbohydrate is a biological molecule consisting of carbon (C), hydrogen (H) and oxygen (O) atoms. Carbohydrates perform numerous roles in living organisms.
Lipid is a substance of biological origin. It comprises a group of molecules that include fats, waxes, sterols and fat-soluble vitamins. The main functions of lipids is storing energy.
DNA is a molecule that carries the genetic instructions used in the growth, development, functioning and reproduction of all living organisms.
Proteins are large biomolecules, consisting of chains of amino acid residues. Proteins perform a vast array of functions within organisms.
A chromosome is a DNA molecule with part or all of the genetic material of an organism.
The cell is the basic structural, functional, and biological unit of all known living organisms. A cell is the smallest unit of life that can replicate independently.
A neuron is an electrically excitable cell that receives, processes, and transmits information through electrical and chemical signals. Neurons are major components of the brain.
A microorganism is a microscopic organism, which may be single-celled or a cluster of cells.
A virus is a small infectious agent that replicates only inside the living cells of other organisms. Viruses can infect all types of life forms, from animals to plants.
Bacteria are microorganisms. They have micrometres in length and number of shapes. Bacteria were among the first life forms to appear on Earth.
Plant cells are eukaryotic cells. There are many types of plant cells, each one has it\'s own function, the most known are cells responsible for photosynthesis.

Plankton are collection of organisms that live in large bodies of water and are unable to swim against a current. They provide a source of food to many large aquatic organisms, such as fish and whales.
An arthropod is an invertebrate animal having an exoskeleton, a segmented body, and paired jointed appendages. Arthropods are for example insects, arachnids, and crustaceans.
A mold is a fungus that grows in the form of multicellular filaments called hyphae. It appears sometimes on food.
A mushroom is the fleshy body of a fungus, typically produced above ground on soil or on its food source.
A leaf is an organ of a vascular plant and is the lateral appendage of the stem. Leaves can be seen in many different shapes, sizes and textures.
A rose is a woody perennial flowering plant of the genus Rosa. There are over a hundred species and thousands of cultivars. They are often armed with sharp prickles.
A fern is a member of a group of vascular plants that reproduce via spores and have neither seeds nor flowers.
The apple tree is a deciduous tree best known for its sweet fruit, the apple. The tree originated in Central Asia.
Jellyfish are softbodied, free-swimming aquatic animals with a gelatinous umbrella-shaped bell and trailing tentacles.
Ants belong to insects. We estimate, that 22,000 species exist, but only 12,500 have been classified.
Butterflies belong to insects. They grow from larvae to beautiful, colorful adults.
A mouse is a small rodent. It has a pointed snout, small rounded ears and scaly tail. The best known mouse species is the common house mouse.
Cat belong to mammals. It is a small and furry. There are more than 70 cat breeds.
Dog is a mammal and also descendant of a wolf. The dog was the first domesticated species, it\'s considered best friend of a human.

Modern humans (Homo sapiens) are the only extant members of the tribe Hominini belonging to the family of great apes. They are characterized by high manual dexterity and a general trend toward more complex societies.
Lion is one of the big cats in the genus Panthera. It has been listed as Vulnerable on the IUCN Red List since 1996, as populations declined by about 43% since the early 1990s.
Elephants are large mammals. Three species are currently recognized: the African elephant, the African elephant, and the Asian elephant. Elephants are common in Africa and Southeast Asia.
Whales are a group of fully sea mammals. Whales feed, mate, give birth, and raise their young at sea. Blue whales range in size to the 29.9 metres and 190 tons.
Tree is a plant with an elongated stem, supporting branches and leaves. It is estimated that there are just over 3 trillion mature trees in the world. The largest tree in the world is redwood.
A forest is a large area dominated by trees. Forests cover approximately 30% of the world\'s land area. They provide shelter to animals and humans, and produce oxygen that is necessary for life.
A river is a natural flowing watercourse, usually freshwater, flowing towards an ocean, sea, lake or another river. The longest river in the World is Amazon in South America.
A canyon is a deep cleft between escarpments or cliffs. It occours in the place where many years ago the river has flown. Best known is the Great Canyon in USA.
A shore is the fringe of land at the edge of a large body of water, such as an ocean, sea, or lake.
A glacier is a body of dense ice that is constantly moving under its own weight. It forms over many years, often centuries. Glaciers form only on land.
A valley is a low area between hills, often with a river running through it. There are two types of valleys: U-shaped and V-shaped, depending on how they were created.
A mountain is a large landform that stretches above the surrounding land. The highest mountain on Earth is Mount Everest in the Himalayas of Asia, whose summit is 8,850 m above mean sea level.
An ocean is a body of saline water that composes much of a planet\'s hydrosphere. Oceans on Earth: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Southern (Antarctic), and Arctic.
A car is a wheeled motor vehicle used for transportation.The year 1886 is regarded as the birth year of the modern car, when German inventor Karl Benz built his Benz Patent-Motorwagen.
A road is a or way on land between two places that has been paved to allow travel by foot or some form of conveyance. The longest road in the World is Pan-American highway.
A house is a building that functions as a home, ranging from simple dwellings and the improvised shacks to complex, fixed structures of wood, brick or concrete.
A lighthouse is a building designed to emit light from a system of lamps and lenses, and to serve as a navigational aid for maritime pilots at sea or on inland waterways.
A boat is a watercraft designed to travel on water. There are few types of boats, human-powered (kayaks, canoes), sailboats or motorboats.
A bridge is a structure built to span physical obstacles. Longest suspension bridge in the world is Akashi Kaikyō bridge (3911m).
A village is a clustered human settlement or community, smaller than a town, with a population ranging from a few hundred to a few thousand.
An opera house is a theatre building used for opera performances that consists of a stage, an orchestra pit, audience seating, and backstage.
A city is a large human settlement. The biggest city in the world is Tokyo in Japan (38140000 inhabitants)
Satellite is an artificial object which has been intentionally placed into orbit. In 1957 the Soviet Union launched the world\'s first artificial satellite, Sputnik 1.
An astronaut or cosmonaut is a person trained by a human spaceflight program to command, pilot, or serve as a crew member of a spacecraft.

A rocket is a missile, spacecraft, aircraft or other vehicle that obtains thrust from a rocket engine. Rockets consist of a tank and a nozzle. They may also have rocket engines, wings, parachutes or wheels.
A Moon lander is a spacecraft design to land on the surface of the Moon. The United States\' Apollo 11 was the first manned mission to land on the Moon, on 20 July 1969.

The Space Shuttle was a partially reusable low Earth orbital spacecraft. The first of four orbital test flights occurred in 1981. The Shuttle fleet\'s total mission time was 1322 days, 19 hours, 21 minutes and 23 seconds.
A launch pad is an above-ground platform from which a rocket-powered missile or space vehicle is vertically launched.
The George C. Marshall Space Flight Center is located in Huntsville, Alabama. MSFC\'s first mission was developing the Saturn launch vehicles for the Apollo moon program.
A telescope is an optical instrument that aids in the observation of remote objects. The first telescopes were invented in the Netherlands at the beginning of the 17th century.
A space station is a spacecraft capable of supporting crew members, which is designed to remain in space for an extended period of time and for other spacecraft to dock.
A comet is an icy small Solar System body that, when passing close to the Sun, warms and begins to release gases. This produces a visible atmosphere and sometimes also a tail.
The Moon is an astronomical body that orbits planet Earth, being Earth\'s only permanent natural satellite.
Pluto was originally considered to be the ninth planet from the Sun, but in 2006 it has been reclassified to a dwarf planet.
Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System. From Earth it can only be seen in the morning or the evening sky.
Venus is the second planet from the Sun. It has no natural satellites. It is named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty.
Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun and the second-smallest planet in the Solar System after Mercury. Mars carries a name of the Roman god of war.
Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only object in the Universe known to harbor life. Earth formed over 4 billion years ago.
Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun. It is the coldest planetary atmosphere in the Solar System, with a minimum temperature of 49 K (−224 °C; −371 °F). Uranus is one of the "ice giants"
Neptune is the eighth and farthest known planet from the Sun in the Solar System. It\'s one of the "ice giants". Neptune is named after the Roman god of the sea.
Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second-largest in the Solar System, after Jupiter. It is a gas giant. Saturn is named after the Roman god of agriculture.
Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System. Jupiter and Saturn are gas giants. Jupiter has been known to astronomers since antiquity.
A red dwarf is a small and relatively cool star. Red dwarfs are the most common type of star in the Milky Way.

The Sun is the star at the center of the Solar System. It is the most important source of energy for life on Earth. About three quarters of the Sun\'s mass consists of hydrogen (~73 percent); the rest is mostly helium (~25 percent).

The Solar System is the gravitationally bound system comprising the Sun and the objects that orbit it (planets, dwarf planets and small Solar System bodies). The Solar System formed 4.6 billion years ago.

A pulsar is a highly magnetized, rotating neutron star or white dwarf, that emits a beam of electromagnetic radiation. This radiation can be observed only when the beam of emission is pointing toward Earth.
A red giant is a luminous giant star of low mass in a late phase of stellar evolution. The appearance of the red giant is from yellow-orange to red.

Gamma-ray bursts are extremely energetic explosions that have been observed in distant galaxies. They are the brightest electromagnetic events known to occur in the universe. Bursts can last from ten milliseconds to several hours.
A galaxy is a gravitationally bound system of stars, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter. Our Solar System is located in Milky Way galaxy.
A galaxy group is an aggregation of galaxies comprising about 50 or fewer gravitationally bound members. The Milky Way galaxy is part of a group of galaxies called the Local Group.

A supercluster is a large group of smaller galaxy groups. It is the largest-known structure of the cosmos. The Milky Way is part of the Local Group galaxy cluster (that contains more than 54 galaxies), which in turn is part of the Laniakea Supercluster.
